_exec_summary.SummaryText:
14-15, 2017.
Operating Procedures - Whole Foods has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.    
Training - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems. Currently, no employees operate the system. They monitor and report to the refrigeration contractor. 
Management of Change - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
Pre-Startup Review - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
Mechanical Integrity - Whole Foods has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented.  
Contractor Qualifications - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Whole Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
Incident Investigation - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each in

oods operations. Whole Foods recently conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) of their ammonia refrigeration system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that PHA. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Whole Foods.

cident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
Compliance Audit - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.   
Hot Work Permits - Whole Foods has developed a best management practice for hot work.  
 

V.	Five-Year Accident History
The Whole Foods facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years. 

VI.	Emergency Response Program
Whole Foods has developed an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  

Whole Foods has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the Chicago Fire Department.  

Whole Foods has coordinated their emergency action plan with the Chicago Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Chicago Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our emergency action plan, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information.

The facility has provided windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.

VII.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Whole F

e that is used for cold storage. 

The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 11,500 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool the storage coolers and freezers. 

IV.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Whole Foods is continuously improving this program. 

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
Employee Participation - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
Process Safety Information - Whole Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. 
Process Hazard Analysis - Whole Foods has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Whole Foods conducted an initial PHA study for the ammonia refrigeration system on September

I.	Introduction
A Risk Management Program has been implemented at the Whole Foods Market Midwest Region Perishable Distribution Center (Whole Foods), for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials. This Program summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to site personnel, contractors, visitors, and the community and environment at large of hazardous chemical releases. The Risk Management Plan (RMP) is organized to correspond with specific U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP, Program 3 of 40 CFR 68.

II.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Risk management and safety are important concerns at Whole Foods; this RMP formalizes and documents these activities. Whole Foods is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and to the environment. It is Whole Foods policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations. 

This RMP has identified potential hazards and has taken steps to design and maintain a safe facility in order to prevent releases, and minimize the consequences of accidental releases, which could occur. This RMP addresses potentially catastrophic chemical releases that could result in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors (public and environmental). Whole Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

III.	Facility Identification
The Whole Foods facility is located at 716 East 111th Street in Chicago, Illinois. The NAICS code for the facility is 49311 - Refrigerated Warehousing and Storage. 

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsit
